results.title: The Green plant
results.brief_description: Aspects of all forms of plant life; their fundamental functions (respiration, intake of food and outlet of waste matter, irritability etc.) Exist here as in the higher forms of life. The basic construction of a plant is described; the way it feeds and grows.

results.title: The Green mile
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, Darkwoods Productions, David Valdes and Frank Darabont
results.brief_description: Set in 1935, inmates at the Cold Mountain Correctional Facility call Death Row “The Green Mile” because of the dark green linoleum that tiles the floor. The story is told as a memoir by Paul Edgecombe (Tom Hanks), now living in an elderly care facility and revisiting his exceptional life, who was head guard on the Green Mile whilst the incidents being recounted occur. A new inmate is brought into his custody: John Coffey (Michael Clarke Duncan), an African American convicted of the brutal murders of young twin white girls. Despite his immense size and fearsome reputation, Coffey seems to be a kind and well-mannered person with a very child-like manner about him. Soon Edgecombe and two of his fellow guards notice that he has the ability to perform miraculous cures, prompting the guards to wonder how such a man could be guilty of the heinous crimes he is charged with. The cast also include James Cromwell as the warden, Sam Rockwell and Graham Greene as inmates awaiting their time in the electric chair, and Harry Dean Stanton as a clever trustee. This film is based on the 1996 serialized novel by Stephen King.

results.title: The Green machine
results.brief_description: The Green Machine is the Australian Army, and, to the accompaniment of Tchaikovsky’s 1812 Overture, we see depicted every aspect of life in the Australian Army of 1976.

results.title: The Green hornet. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Ford Beebe and Ray Taylor
results.brief_description: Volume 2 contains chapters 7 to 13. Based on the successful radio serial of the same name, Britt Reid (Gordon Jones) as the Green Hornet and his crime fighting partner, Kato (Keye Luke) battle against organised crime’s king-pins. The Green Hornet is the direct descendant of the famous masked crime fighter, The Lone Ranger. He’s the Lone Ranger’s grand nephew. This movie serial used the same principle characters that featured in the radio play as well as the famous Hornet musical signature (Flight of the Bumble Bee) and gadgetry such as a gas gun to incapacitate criminals. Also used is the voice of Al Hodge, the radio Green Hornet, which was heard when crusading publisher Britt Reid spoke from behind the Hornet mask. Also stars Anne Nagel as Lenore Case.

results.title: The Green city
results.brief_description: Shows how green open space is being thoughtlessly gobbled up by the urbanising process. Demonstrates how development can take place without excessive destruction and illustrates various situations in different parts of the United States. Describes man’s changing environment and fortells the consequences if this change is permitted to take place without careful planning.

results.title: The Green berets (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Michael Wayne, Batjac Productions, Warner Bros Pictures, Seven Arts, John Wayne and Ray Kellogg
results.brief_description: After extensive training, Colonel Michael Kirby selects two platoons from the U.S. Special forces - known as the Green Berets - for guerilla warfare at Anang. The soldiers are needed to widen the ‘killing zone’ around a Strike Camp in Viet Cong Territory. One of the most controversial movies about the Vietnamese Conflict, ‘Green berets’ stars John Wayne and David Janssen.

results.title: The Greeks: crucible of civilization
results.creator_credit: Cassian Harrison, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Atlantic Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Narrated by Liam Neeson, these three episodes examine the rise and eventual collapse of the ancient Greek empire in the fifth and fourth centuries BC. In episode one, “The Revolution”, we look at the rise of classical Athens through the eyes of Cleisthenes, a nobleman who assisted in the development of democracy. Initially a small city-state, Athens was riddled by aristocratic antagonisms and fear of the warrior city-state of Sparta. By developing a political system of “equals” rather than an economy of tyranny, Cleisthenes and his fellow citizens developed the world’s first democracy. In episode two, “The Golden Age”, the rise of democratic Athens was threatened by the might of the Persian Empire. Under the generalship of Themistocles, the Athenian navy conquered the Persians and the resulting victory gave rise to a Greek empire that intellectually and economically dominated the Mediterranean world. Over this period, Greek culture developed the roots to modern philosophy, science, rationalism, art, drama and culture. Under the leadership of Pericles, the Parthenon was built and the city of Athens grew into the world’s most important state. In episode three, “Empire of the Mind”, the death of Pericles leads to civil violence and dissent and the fracturing of democracy into mob rule. Critics of the state, such as Socrates, are punished and executed but with the fall of Greece as a great military power there arises instead a cultural legacy of reason and philosophy which sees the Socratic method becoming the founding basis of Western civilisation.

results.title: The Greeks in search of meaning
results.creator_credit: John H. Secondari and Helen Jean Secondari
results.brief_description: Recreates the concerns and achievements of the Greeks in the 5th century B.C. Eternal philosophical and moral debates are dramatised through the dialogues of the era’s great thinkers. Includes excerpts from Antigone by Sophocles, and Lysistrata by Aristophanes.
